figure_1.title: Figure 1.
figure_1.caption: Figure 1. Flow chart of the selection of study subjects. aGraduate schools of medicine, medical schools, and hospitals affiliated with medical schools (main hospitals); bDepartments of general medicine, general internal medicine, primary care medicine, family medicine, community medicine, and other similar department names; cDepartments of cardiology, circulatory medicine, endovascular medicine, and other similar names; dOn January 1, 2020.

figure_2.title: Figure 2.
figure_2.caption: Figure 2. Research field coverage of the surveyed articles (as a percentage of the total number of articles by field) in the 2 groups. General medicine group: 3,894 total articles (including duplicates) in 92 fields. Cardiology group: 13,170 total papers (including duplicates) in 99 fields. Research fields that comprised <2.0% each (75 in general medicine and 91 in cardiology) are not shown on the graphs, with the exception of primary health care).

figure_4.title: Figure 4.
figure_4.caption: Figure 4. Scatterplots and regression lines of the number of articles and fields for each researcher transformed to the common logarithm.

claims.sentence: In cardiology, 96 departments in 81 universities met the inclusion criteria, with 96 eligible research authors (Fig. 1).

Open in a new tab
Figure 1.
Of the 3,894 papers (including duplicates) encompassing 92 fields of general medicine, most were in the category of general and internal medicine (11.9%; 465 papers; Fig. 2).

Open in a new tab
Figure 2.

Research fields that comprised <2.0% each (75 in general medicine and 91 in cardiology) are not shown on the graphs, with the exception of primary health care).Figure 3 shows the relationship between the proportion of the total number of researchers by field and the number of articles/individual researchers by field.

Open in a new tab
Figure 3.

Boundary values belong to the lower group; cValues on/in the boxes indicate the number of research fields in general medicine and cardiology.Figure 4 shows the scatterplot generated after applying common logarithm transformation of data on numbers of published articles and fields for 118 researchers in general medicine (excluding 10 researchers with 0 articles) and 96 researchers in cardiology.

Open in a new tab
Figure 4.
However, taking into account the proportion of articles by research field could offset the effect of staff numbers (Fig. 2).

Even taking into account differences in staff numbers between the 2 specialties, the general medicine field seems to be a heterogeneous group (Fig. 3) that contains researchers who conduct multidisciplinary research (Fig. 4).
In cardiology, 96 departments in 81 universities met the inclusion criteria, with 96 eligible research authors (Fig. 1).

In cardiology, 96 departments in 81 universities met the inclusion criteria, with 96 eligible research authors (Fig. 1).
Of the 3,894 papers (including duplicates) encompassing 92 fields of general medicine, most were in the category of general and internal medicine (11.9%; 465 papers; Fig. 2).
Figure 3 shows the relationship between the proportion of the total number of researchers by field and the number of articles/individual researchers by field.

Figure 4 shows the scatterplot generated after applying common logarithm transformation of data on numbers of published articles and fields for 118 researchers in general medicine (excluding 10 researchers with 0 articles) and 96 researchers in cardiology.
However, taking into account the proportion of articles by research field could offset the effect of staff numbers (Fig. 2).

Even taking into account differences in staff numbers between the 2 specialties, the general medicine field seems to be a heterogeneous group (Fig. 3) that contains researchers who conduct multidisciplinary research (Fig. 4).
However, taking into account the proportion of articles by research field could offset the effect of staff numbers (Fig. 2).

Even taking into account differences in staff numbers between the 2 specialties, the general medicine field seems to be a heterogeneous group (Fig. 3) that contains researchers who conduct multidisciplinary research (Fig. 4).
However, taking into account the proportion of articles by research field could offset the effect of staff numbers (Fig. 2).

Even taking into account differences in staff numbers between the 2 specialties, the general medicine field seems to be a heterogeneous group (Fig. 3) that contains researchers who conduct multidisciplinary research (Fig. 4).
